discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
From the Run Time line, FortiOS is reporting the system’s uptime (not how long the diag sys top command has been running), so answer B is incorrect. Also, having a process in the R (running) state does not imply it needs to be restarted, so E is incorrect.

The correct answer is ACD:

A – The last column (“0”) shows miglogd is on CPU core 0.
C – Pressing M to sort by memory would place miglogd at the top because it has the highest memory usage (6.8).
D – The cmdbsvr process is shown using 2.4% memory (the second‐to‐last column).

https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Using-the-diagnose-sys-top-CLI-command/ta-p/190238

choices.E: If the newcli daemon continues to be in the R state, it will need to be manually restarted.
choices.C: The miglogd daemon would be on top of the list, if the administrator pressed m on the keyboard.
choices.B: The diagnose sys top command has been running for 18 minutes.
choices.A: The miglogd daemon is running on CPU core ID 0.
choices.D: The cmdbsvr process is occupying 2.4% of the total user memory space.
The output shows all prefixes advertised by all neighbors as well as the local router
choices.C: The advertised prefix of 10.20.30.0/24 is being advertised through the redistribution of another routing protocol.
choices.A: The advertised prefix of 10.20.30.0/24 was configured using the network command.
choices.B: The first four prefixes are being advertised using a legacy route advertisement.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Correct answer is AD.

A. The advertised prefix of 10.20.30.0/24 was configured using the network command.
The origin code for 10.20.30.0/24 indicates an IGP source (usually shown as “i”), meaning it was originated locally via a network statement rather than via redistribution.

D. The output shows all prefixes advertised by all neighbors as well as the local router.
When you run 'get router info bgp network' without specifying a prefix, it displays the complete local BGP table. This includes all prefixes that are in the router’s BGP database—whether learned from neighbors or originated locally per the configuration and active policies.

choices.B: A UDP session with packets sent and received
choices.C: A TCP session waiting for the SYN ACK
choices.D: A TCP session waiting for FIN ACK
choices.A: A UDP session with only one packet received

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
The correct answer is AC.
In FortiGate, “ephemeral” sessions typically refer to sessions that are either not fully established or consist of only a single packet. Specifically:

A. A UDP session with only one packet received – This qualifies as ephemeral because there has been no return traffic (only one packet).
C. A TCP session waiting for the SYN ACK – This also qualifies as ephemeral because the session is still half-open and not fully established.

questions.question_text: In which two states is a given session categorized as ephemeral? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correction: Answer A

The issue is an "Authentication type mismatch," which indicates that one device has authentication enabled (possibly with a password), while the other does not. The password or authentication type mismatch is causing the OSPF adjacency to fail. However, the debug output does not explicitly confirm that a password has been configured on the local router—it only indicates a mismatch in authentication types.

Selected Answer: D
"Authentication type mismatch": This error message explicitly states that the two routers have conflicting authentication configurations.
"AuType 0": This field in the Hello packet indicates that the sending router is not expecting any authentication.

Answer D.

Selected Answer: A
Scratch that I read it wrong, A is the only possible one then

Selected Answer: D
D is the only false one, A COULD be false, but with the output given it could also be true we just don't know, therefore we cannot assume it is false, D is the only 100% false statement.

Selected Answer: A
Correction : this FGT received the message AuType =0, this the other side does not have authentication configured. But it does not say which authentication is used on local ... AuType 1 (password) or AuType 2 (crypto)
 So for me still A

Selected Answer: A
Since AuType=0 means that this FGT (local) does not have authentication configured
Looking at the response ... means the other side has authentication configured

Selected Answer: D
Type 0 means that authentication is not configured

choices.C: The two FortiGate devices attempting adjacency are in area 0.0.0.0.
choices.B: The Hello packet is being sent from an OSPF router with ID 0.0.0.112.
choices.D: One FortiGate device is configured to require authentication, while the other is not.
choices.A: A password has been configured on the local OSPF router but is not shown in the output.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Correct answer is AC.
- Option A is correct because the "State/PfxRcd" column for neighbor 100.64.1.254 shows 1, indicating one prefix was received.
- Option C is correct because neighbor 100.64.1.254 has MsgRcvd = 18, meaning 18 BGP messages (packets) were received.
- Option B is incorrect because the neighbor 100.64.2.254 is in "Active" state, which means the TCP connection has not been established.
- Option D is incorrect because "Active" refers to the session state, not prefix calculation. No prefixes are being received from this neighbor.

choices.D: The local FortiGate is still calculating the prefixes received from the BGP neighbor 100.64.2.254.
choices.C: The local FortiGate has received 18 packets from a BGP neighbor.
choices.B: The TCP connection with BGP neighbor 100.64.2.254 was successful.
choices.A: The local FortiGate has received one prefix from BGP neighbor 100.64.1.254.
